Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC Stevens: Center for Cyber-SMART

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will undertake activities to launch a new Industry-University Cooperative Research Center for cyber research, hosted jointly by Georgetown University, Stevens Institute of Technology, and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The vision of the center is to foster multi-disciplinary collaborations for the revolutionizing roles of cyber security, management, applications, regulation, and training (Cyber SMART). These collaborations are necessary for the laws, policies, and regulations to develop and evolve in tandem with new cyber technological innovations. Cyber SMART brings researchers from business, computer science, engineering and law from multiple universities to collaborate with public and private sector affiliates to define the cross-disciplinary agenda.

The cross-disciplinary teams at Stevens include the fields of economics, financial engineering, physics, computer science, mathematical sciences and artificial intelligence. The teams will examine critical issues with the shared goal of better understanding the effects of technological change on the financial industry through collaboration with the partnering universities. The Stevens site aims to address fundamental research challenges by examining three different technologies: i) artificial intelligence in the form of AI-assisted financial decision systems; ii) distributed ledgers and smart contract technologies used to create new types of payment platforms and exchanges; iii) quantum computing focused on transforming foundational processes in cyber-security and communication.

The research resulting from this site will benefit the economy by reducing uncertainty related to introducing new technologies and new regulations. In particular, the research will help policy makers and industry participants in better understanding and managing risks and unintended market disruptions. It will also help industry participants learn better decision making in the face of technological and regulatory uncertainty. Moreover, it may broaden participation in STEM disciplines in the financial industry. It will involve local communities, and students from underrepresented groups starting at the high school level through Stevens’ Center for Innovation in Engineering and Science Education.

This planning grant will support a workshop held at Stevens, jointly with RPI, to engage with potential industry affiliates of Cyber SMART to explore research projects of mutual interest. Stevens has proximity to Manhattan and ties with the financial industry; RPI is equidistant from Boston and New York City, and has ties with financial and technology industry; Georgetown is in Washington DC, in proximity to regulators. The workshop will involve participation from banks, insurers, regulators, exchanges, and FinTech companies. The content generated from the workshop, such as agenda, presentations, will be permanently hosted at Stevens’ Hanlon Financial Systems Lab.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project undertook activities to launch the Center for Research toward Advancing Financial Technologies (CRAFT) in collaboration between Stevens Institute of Technology (Stevens) and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (Rensselaer) to conduct and advance interdisciplinary fintech research, innovation, and workforce training. The vision and mission of the Center will be achieved through collaborative cross-disciplinary research, training and education, not just for students but for industry and policy makers. The proposed site at Stevens will bring together a range of complementary capabilities, in finance, financial engineering, economics, physics, computer science, artificial intelligence, human computer interaction, information systems, software engineering, engineered systems, ethics, and policy. The Center PIs and Co-PIs actively participated the NSF IUCRC Bootcamp training, jointly organized the planning workshop with more than 90 participants from both academia and industry, and successfully submitted the Phase I IUCRC full proposal during the planning grant period.

As the result of the planning project, the Stevens site has recruited 30 research faculty members from the School of Business, the School of Engineering and Science, and the School of Systems and Enterprises to support Center’s defined research agenda. During the planning phase of the center, the CRAFT team conducted numerous interviews with the industry constituents. Our discussions strongly validated our view that US financial services industry demands new expertise where computer science research is cohesively supported by expertise in finance and economics, business management, law and regulation, risk analytics, behavioral and social sciences. Four key unmet fintech research and innovation needs emerged from our interviews: a) develop explainable, fair and accessibility-aware methods that foster financial technology innovation; b) provide resiliency in response to disruptive technologies, climate change, and natural disasters; c) enable fintech innovations to provide better accountability, privacy, and social responsibility; d) bridge regulatory and industry needs to innovate and provide a neutral forum for regulators and industry on key challenges. Overall, these plans set a foundation for current and future industry needs.

During the project, Stevens and RPI were able to engage and recruit 18 financial industry organizations as the funding members of the Center with a total of $625,000 committed membership fees to support the center research agenda. These organizations include the world major investment banks, leading index providers, and credit rating firms, financial exchanges, industry associations, and the world technology leaders for the financial industry. In the course of recruiting these firms to provide funding support for CRAFT, we have had extensive conversations with each prospective partner about their specific sense of research priorities.

Moreover, the Governor’s Office of the State of New Jersey is also engaged and very supportive of the effort.  As well, we are in close contact with several of the key financial regulators, including the Securities & Exchange Commission, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Department of the Treasury, FINRA, and the Federal Reserve. We expect that they will also participate, as affiliates, in the CRAFT programs. This involvement provides us with an important window on Fintech research priorities as seen from the regulatory side of the financial industry.

In collaboration with RPI and the industry partners, Stevens has clearly defined its research focus on financial technology through combining its existing fundamental research in the areas of artificial intelligence, quantum computing, distributed ledgers and associated smart contract technologies, along with its expertise in finance, business, ethics, regulation, and policy. The results of the proposed Center will have a strong effect on the economy by reducing uncertainty related to introducing new innovative technologies. They will allow policy makers and industry participants to better understand and manage risks, thus reducing the possibility of unintended market disruptions. With respect to education, the project will lead to technologies and processes that can be used in education and training. Moreover, the proposed workshops and contests for high school students will broaden participation in STEM disciplines, bringing in more women and underrepresented minorities.
